title: 103_hr3361
content: The "Maritime Revitalization Act of 1993" is the short title of this Act. It includes modifications in excise tax on transportation of passengers by water. The "Maritime Revitalization Act of 1993" includes amendments to the excise tax on water transportation of passengers. The tax rate for vessels with accommodations for at least 150 passengers is set at 5 percent of the amount paid by each passenger for a covered voyage. The definition of covered voyages is expanded to include trips with a port of call outside the United States or its territories. These changes will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. EXCISE TAX ON CONTAINERS USED TO IMPORT OR EXPORT COMMERCIAL CARGO. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a tax on containers used for importing or exporting cargo. A tax of $15 per 20-foot equivalent unit is imposed on taxable container use, to be paid by the shipper at the time of exportation or entry. Taxable container use refers to loading a container with commercial cargo. A tax of $15 per 20-foot equivalent unit is imposed on taxable container use, which refers to loading or unloading commercial cargo on a commercial vessel at a port in the United States. The terms 'commercial cargo', 'commercial vessel', and 'port' are defined under section 4462, and the definition of 'United States' includes its possessions. Special rules similar to those in section 4462 apply for this section. A clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters in chapter 36 of the Code. SEC. 4 introduces the Maritime Revitalization Fund under Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with an effective date of January 1, 1996. The Maritime Revitalization Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by net revenues from maritime taxes. The Fund is created under Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective January 1, 1996. The Maritime Revitalization Fund is funded by maritime taxes, including taxes on transportation of passengers by water and containers used for importing or exporting cargo. The Fund can only be used for specific expenditures outlined in appropriation Acts. The Maritime Revitalization Fund is funded by maritime taxes and can only be used for specific expenditures outlined in appropriation Acts. The proposed amendment to the Merchant Marine Act, 1936, by H.R. 2151 of the 103d Congress, allows for expenditures to carry out similar laws.
